title: Headache (Cephalalgia)
content: A headache is pain or discomfort in the head, scalp, or neck. Common types include tension headaches, migraines, and cluster headaches. Most headaches are not serious and can be treated with pain relievers, relaxation techniques, and lifestyle changes.
treatments: Rest in a dark, quiet room
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate medical attention if headache is sudden and severe, accompanied by fever, stiff neck, confusion, seizures, double vision, weakness, numbness, or difficulty speaking.

title: Fever (Pyrexia)
content: A fever is a temporary increase in body temperature, often due to illness. A temperature above 38°C (100.4°F) is generally considered a fever. Fever is a sign that your body is fighting an infection.
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical attention for fever above 39.4°C (103°F), fever lasting more than 3 days, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, persistent vomiting, difficulty breathing, or skin rash.

title: Sore Throat (Pharyngitis)
content: A sore throat is pain, scratchiness, or irritation of the throat that often worsens when swallowing. The most common cause is a viral infection (cold or flu). Bacterial infections like strep throat require antibiotic treatment.
symptoms: Pain or scratchy sensation in throat
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if sore throat is severe or lasts longer than a week, difficulty swallowing or breathing, high fever, blood in saliva, frequent sore throats, or lump in neck.

title: Cough
content: A cough is your body's way of responding to irritants in your throat and airways. Occasional coughing is normal, but a persistent cough can indicate an underlying condition. Coughs can be dry or productive (with mucus).
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical attention for cough lasting more than 3 weeks, coughing up blood, difficulty breathing, high fever, unexplained weight loss, or night sweats.

title: Stomach Pain (Abdominal Pain)
content: Abdominal pain refers to discomfort in the area between the chest and pelvis. Most cases are not serious and can be related to digestion, but severe pain may indicate a serious condition requiring immediate attention.
treatments: Avoid solid food for a few hours
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care for severe pain, pain with fever, bloody stool, persistent vomiting, swollen abdomen, pain during pregnancy, or pain lasting more than 24-48 hours.

title: Back Pain
content: Back pain is one of the most common medical problems. It can range from a dull, constant ache to sudden, sharp pain. Most back pain gets better within a few weeks without treatment.
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if pain persists beyond a few weeks, is severe and doesn't improve with rest, spreads down legs (especially below knee), causes weakness/numbness/tingling, or is accompanied by unexplained weight loss.

title: Fatigue
content: Fatigue is a feeling of constant tiredness or weakness that can be physical, mental, or both. It's different from simply feeling drowsy or sleepy. Fatigue can be a symptom of many different conditions.
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if fatigue persists despite rest, is accompanied by unexplained weight loss, fever, or other symptoms, significantly impacts daily life, or if you suspect an underlying condition.

title: Chest Pain
content: Chest pain can have many causes, from muscle strain to heart problems. While not all chest pain is serious, it's important to recognize when it might indicate a heart attack or other emergency.
symptoms: Pain spreading to arm, jaw, or back
treatments: For suspected heart attack: call emergency immediately
For muscle strain: rest, ice, pain relievers
when_to_see_doctor: CALL EMERGENCY (112) IMMEDIATELY if chest pain is sudden and severe, accompanied by shortness of breath, pain spreading to arm/jaw/back, sweating, nausea, or dizziness. These could be signs of a heart attack.

title: Nausea and Vomiting
content: Nausea is an uneasiness of the stomach that often comes before vomiting. Vomiting is the forcible emptying of stomach contents through the mouth. These symptoms can be caused by many conditions.
treatments: Rest and avoid solid foods temporarily
BRAT diet when ready (bananas, rice, applesauce, toast)
when_to_see_doctor: Seek medical care if vomiting persists more than 24 hours, there's blood in vomit, signs of dehydration, severe abdominal pain, high fever, or stiff neck with headache.

title: Dizziness
content: Dizziness is a term used to describe a range of sensations including feeling faint, woozy, weak, or unsteady. Vertigo creates the false sense that you or your surroundings are spinning or moving.
when_to_see_doctor: Seek immediate care if dizziness is accompanied by sudden severe headache, chest pain, difficulty breathing, numbness/weakness, fainting, rapid heartbeat, or head injury.

title: Common Cold
content: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract. It's usually harmless, although it might not feel that way. Many types of viruses can cause a common cold, with rhinoviruses being the most common.
causes: Spread through droplets or touching contaminated surfaces
treatments: Honey for cough (not for children under 1)
Pain relievers for aches and fever
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if symptoms last more than 10 days, high fever (above 39.4°C/103°F), fever returning after improvement, severe sinus pain, or difficulty breathing.

title: Influenza (Flu)
content: Influenza is a contagious respiratory illness caused by influenza viruses. It can cause mild to severe illness and sometimes lead to death. The best way to prevent flu is annual vaccination.
symptoms: Vomiting and diarrhea (more common in children)
treatments: Pain relievers for fever and aches
when_to_see_doctor: Seek emergency care for difficulty breathing, persistent chest pain, confusion, severe vomiting, or flu-like symptoms that improve but return with fever and worse cough.

title: Diabetes Overview
content: Diabetes is a chronic disease where the body either doesn't produce enough insulin or can't effectively use the insulin it produces. This leads to elevated blood glucose levels that can damage organs over time.
causes: Type 1: Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells
Type 2: Insulin resistance, often linked to obesity and lifestyle
when_to_see_doctor: See a doctor if you experience symptoms of diabetes, have risk factors, or if you have diabetes and experience very high or low blood sugar, signs of ketoacidosis, or other complications.

title: High Blood Pressure (Hypertension)
content: High blood pressure is a common condition where the force of blood against artery walls is too high. It often has no symptoms but can lead to serious health problems like heart disease and stroke if untreated.
when_to_see_doctor: Get regular blood pressure checks. Seek immediate care if blood pressure is very high (180/120 or higher) or accompanied by chest pain, severe headache, difficulty breathing, or neurological symptoms.

title: Anxiety Disorders
content: Anxiety disorders involve more than temporary worry or fear. For a person with an anxiety disorder, the anxiety does not go away and can get worse over time, interfering with daily activities.
when_to_see_doctor: Seek help if anxiety interferes with work, relationships, or daily life, if you have suicidal thoughts, or if anxiety is accompanied by depression or substance use problems.

title: Depression
content: Depression is a common but serious mood disorder that affects how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. It requires treatment and is not something people can simply 'snap out of'.
when_to_see_doctor: Seek help immediately if you have thoughts of suicide or self-harm. Also see a doctor if symptoms persist for more than two weeks, significantly impact daily functioning, or if depression returns after improvement.
